REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 5 Report of the State Auditor State of Nebraska AUDITOR'S OFFICE Lincoln To. Hon. S. R. McKelvie, Governor of Nebraska. My Dear Sir: In accordance -with the laws of this state relating to the Department of the State Auditor, I am submitting herewith my report for the bien - nial period from December 1, 1918, to November 30, 1920. You will find on Statement No. 1 a tabulation of the "Resources and Liabilities of the State" as required by Statute. It has been cus - tomary in the past for the State Auditor to prepare merely a statement of the funds. It seems to me, however, that the statute is plain; further - more, the people of this State will be interested to know something definite in regard to the various kinds of property held in the name of the State and the value thereof. Hence I have prepared such a state - ment showing the total value of the resources of the State of Nebraska as of November 30, 1920. to be $65,077,384.02. Liabilities there are none, barring current expense bills. In preparing this statement the question arose as to the value of the delinquent taxes. Naturally there remains for every county a residue of uncollectable taxes, which increases in bulk, but decreases in value as the years go by. An attempt was made to ascertain the actual amount of money, net, that will probably come into the State treasury from the taxes now outstanding, including interest and deducting the collection fee; eventually the taxes were placed in different groups and the value carefully estimated on basis of past experience, as follows: Taxes delinquent iip to three years (1919, 1918, 1917), 97% of amount outstanding on January 1, 1920. Taxes delinquent 4 to 9 years (1916 to 1911), 25"£ of an/iunt out - standing January 1, 1920. Taxes delinquent 10 and more years (1910 and prior), 2% of amount outstanding on January 1, 1920. Bad Tax Accounts Two per cent average value on the taxes delinquent for ten or more years may at first sight appear an exceedingly low valuation, but judg - ing by past experience, it is, if anything, too high. A reference to State - ment No. 5A, where the amount of the 1919 collections are placed op - posite the amounts delinquent for the various years in the respective counties will show how small are the amounts collected on the taxes de - linquent ten years and more. The receipts from the 1910 and prior ac - counts during 1919 amounted only to about two pro mill, so this rate will have to continue for some ten more years in order to net the two per cent.

6 The trouble is that over 80%. of these old taxes originated before 1900 and represent accumulations of uncollected taxes since the very organization of the State, and they are well night worthless. In all the counties of the State, except Burt and Cheyenne, the amount of taxes for 1900 and prior total $716,061.38. The corresponding receipts during the year 1919 were only $294.10, which means but forty-one cents col - lected on every $1,000.00 outstanding, which is hardly worth while; at that rate it would take those counties over two thousand years to pay these old items. Burt county in 1919 had a successful Scavenger Tax Sale, which netted the State $558.36. Cheyenne county paid $71.09, of which $62.75 was sent in by the new county of Morrill, perhaps also proceeds of a Scavenger Tax Sale on old Cheyenne county taxes, taken over by Mor - rill county, when organized. Such events help to bring up the average. In 1903 a law was passed (Statute 6494), amended in 1915 (Chapter 110 of the 1915 Session Laws), providing a way to have uncdllectable Ees stricken from the books and the losses through Scavenger Tax es credited on the books at the State Auditor's office. However, the inty Treasurers do not seem to pay much attention to this law; also it is a question whether the law does not conflict with the Constitution, which provides (Article 9, Section 4) : "Nor shall commutation for tch) taxes be authorized in any form whatever." Nevertheless, some the counties have received credits of uncollectable taxes, notably dison County, which in consequence thereof is the only county in the State today which does not stand charged on the State tax ledgers with delinquent taxes for 1900 and prior. Since the Constitution appears to absolutely prohibit the commuta - tion of taxes no matter how worthless, I would recommend that the State Auditor be required to transfer to a "Suspension Ledger" all amounts of delinquent taxes dating back to 1900 and prior. This will clear the current ledgers and will not affect the counties, which may keep after the old accounts and endeavor to collect them if they choose, and the portion belonging to the State should be sent in as before, to be credited to the consolidated taxes as provided by present statute. Revenues and Expenditures Statement No. 2 shows the revenues and expenditures for the bien - nium from December 1, 1918, to November 30, 1920, the receipts repre - senting the actual amounts paid into the State Treasury and the expen - ditures the warrants -written as per statements Nos. 6 and 7. It will be noticed that the revenues totaled $22,810,664.84. Of this the sum of $567,462.59 representing items going into "Trust Funds" for permaEent investments as shown on Schedule 2A, leaving $22,243,202.25 available for payment of current expenditures. The expenditures during the biennium totaled $22,637,7S1.70, thus ex - ceeding the available revenue $394,579.45. I might say in connection herewith, that this appears to be the first

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 7 time for the State Auditor to present a report of the totals in classified and condensed form, and to make the figures check with the State Treasury. Perhaps this is not required by statute, but this matter of Revenues and Expenditures being so important, an effort has been made to present an elucidative statement, showing on the one hand the main purposes for which the money was expended, in amounts as well as per - centages, and on the other hand the sources from which the revenues were derived. It will be noticed from Statement No. 2 that virtually one-haU" of the revenues were derived from direct taxes levied on property, the two next largest items being "Earnings of Institutions" ($2,582,800.60) and "Auto Licenses" (12,340,980.84). As to the expenditures it will be noticed that about seven-eightha went for special purposes designated by the Legislature over which the That the expense of the Executive Departments stands at the bottom of the list calls attention to the fact that the wages of the employees in these departments are still on a 1913 — before-the-war — basis, and entirely inadequate. There has been a substantial increase in the wages paid at the University and other institutions, and a higher scale of wages ranges in the newer departments, such as the Civil Administration Code De - partments, but to employees in the old executive offices virtually the same wages are still being paid that were paid ten and more years ago. I would recommend that the employees in the Executive Departments be placed on the same basis with the more favored ones. The Executive Departments are, after all, the most important ones and should not be continuously discriminated against. In making up the statement of Revenues and Expenditures, those of the State Hail and the Depositors' Guarantee Fund have not been in- cluded, as these are not State funds in the ordinary sense of the word. but represent, rather, co-operative enterprises under State supervision. The receipts and disbursements of the State Hail account may be found on Statement Nos. 6 and 7 along with other appropriation and fund accounts. ■xecutive officers virtually have no control, as follows: Educational purposes $ 8,828,210.18 or 39.00% Roads and Bridges 6,308,202.67 or 27.86% Charitable and Penal Institutions 4,792.499.15 or 21.17% Total $19,928,912.00 or 88.03% Only about one-eighth went for departmental expenses, as follows : Code Departments ? 1,036,967.81 or 4.58% Sundry Boards and Commissions and Miscellaneous _ 608,750.74 or 2.69% Judiciary Departments 492,509.10 or 2.18% Legislative Departments 289,536.12 or 1.28%. Executive Departments :.....-. 281,105.93 or 1.24% Total _ $ 2,708,869.70 or 11.97% 2,708,869.70 or 11.97%

8 Fiscal Years In keeping the State accounts this office is hampered on account of the different "years" that must be observed. The "fiscal year" of the State of Nebraska runs from December to November and the Auditor's report is to be made on that basis. The County Treasurers, on the other hand, make their settlement with the State Auditor on the basis of a calendar year, January to December. The appropriations by the Leg - islature are made on the basis of a biennium beginning April 1 and ending March 31, and the Auditor in his report must cover appropria - tions made for two different bienniums. The United States Govern - ment finally has a fiscal year running from July to June, and makes its settlement on that basis. It has been suggested that the fiscal year for the State of Nebraska be changed to run from July to June to conform with the fiscal year of the Federal Government. I would heartily endorse such a movement. The County Treasurers should then be required to observe this year and to make their settlement with the State Auditor on basis of July 1. Most of the taxes for the preceding year will then have been collected and it will be possible to strike an all-around balance covering appro - priations, and expenditures as well as receipts, and conforming with the County Treasurers and the State Treasury as well as the United States Government. Operating and Capital Expenditures I would recommend that the Legislature in making its appropria - tions observe a distinction between operating expenses ond Capital ex - penditures. Money spent to keep things running is money spent and gone and means simply a loss. But money expended to erect a new building or to buy the grounds for some, or the furniture and equipment, or money expended for new additions to buildings does not represent a loss, but merely a change in the kind of assets. If in the future the Legislature will put the appropriations for maintenance and repairs separate from the appropriations for new grounds, buildings and other property to be acquired, this will enable the State Auditor at the end of the biennium to report the actual cost of running the State during the period covered, and also the amount of new property acquired. Special Levies Another change I should welcome would be the abolition of the special levies for special purposes, and the granting of fixed appropria - tions by the Legislature instead. I am sure this would make for economy and it would greatly simplify the keeping of the accounts in this offire as well as in the State Treasurer's office. It would cause a considerable saving in the expense of providing blank warrants. The cost of blank warrants used to be about $7.50 per thousand; about twenty-four different kinds of blanks are required for warrants drawn on the different funds. The cost of the blank warrants if purchased in large quantities now is about $17.00 per thousand, and when printed in smaller quantities about $37.00 per thousand will have to be paid.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 9 Registration of Bonds The face value of the bonds sent to the Auditor's Office for registra - tion during the biennium amounted to $22,124,089.52. This is almost exactly three times as much as registered during the preceding biennium. The looking up of the history, etc., and the registration of these many bonds involve considerable work and expense at the State Audi - tor's Office, the expense for postage alone in returning the registered bonds being quite an item. I would therefor recommend that a charge of ten cents be made for each bond registered, payable to the Auditor by the county, district, or subdivision bonded, the money to be turned into the State Treasury. Examinations of County Offices In 1919 a law was passed (Chapter 73, Laws of 1919) requiring all books, accounts and affairs of all county officers in every county of the State to be examined, at least every two years, by the direction and under the supervision of the Auditor of Public Accounts. The Legisla - ture appropriated salaries for four examiners, but expense money hardly sufficient for two, and only two examiners were employed by me and their activities limited to the examination of county treasurers. Nothing much could have been accomplished by having two additional men, as they would hardly have been sufficient to examine even two counties such as Douglas and Lancaster, if all the county offices were to be ex - amined and the work done properly. For the next biennium I am there - fore asking for only two County Treasurer Examiners. Unless a sufficient appropriation is made to permit the employment of the required large force, I would recommend that the law be changed so as to require the county boards to have all their offices ex - amined once every two years by some public accountant, instead of hav - ing the work performed by the State. Further, in regard to appointing the State Accountant: The statute provides that it shall be the duty of the Auditor of Public Accounts "to examine books, accounts, vouchers, records and expenditures of all State officers, State bureaus, boards and commissioners, institutions," etc., and "to this end the Auditor of Public Accounts shall, with the approval of the Governor, appoint an expert accountant, whose entire time shall be devoted to the service of the State as directed by the Auditor." To un - derstand why the approval of the Governor is made necessary for the appointment of the expert accountant who is to work as directed by the Auditor and who is to assist in the performance of the duties of the Auditor, it should be borne in mind that this proviso was made in 1913 when the Legislature and Governor were Democratic and the State Auditor Republican. This proviso having its origin in mere party poli - tics. I would recommend that the words "with the approval of the Governor" be eliminated from the statute, thus placing upon the State Auditor the sole responsibility for his assistants. All of which is respectfully submitted. GEO. W. MARSH, State Auditor. State House, Lincoln, Nebraska, December, 1920.

208 STATEMENT MO. 11 A, SHOWING THE STATE LEVY BY FUNDS TO THE HONORABLE MEMBERS OF THE BOARD OF EQUALIZA - TION AND ASSESSMENT: Herewith I submit to you an estimate of the levy needed to raise the necessary sum lor the State General Fund to meet the first half of the appropriations made by the 1919 session of the Legislature, together with au estimate of the amount that will be raised from the special levies. The assessed or one-fifth value of the State for 1919 is approximately $572,000,000.00. The total appropriations made by the Legislature out of the State General Fund is $6,905,291.08. One-half of the total appropriation is $3,452,645.00, and from this amount should be deducted the sum of $140,631.93, which the Treasuicr has already paid for emergency claims, Legislative expenses, Relief Bills, Etc. There is en hand iu th e General Fund $250,000.00, which added to the amount alrcadp paid for Emergency Claims, etc., amounts to $j'J0,- 631.93, which deducted from $3,452,645.00, leaves a balance to be raised for the General Fund of $3,062,013.97. Taking into consideration the footings of the tax list will show a ma- terial increase over the grand total as reported on the Abstract of As- sessment, owing to some irregulatities that are under process ol correc- tion at this time, and not reported, I am ol" theopinion that a 4. SO cf a rlevy is ample to take care of the needs of the General Fund. It might be stated that of the appropriations of the last Legislature r 09,187.00 was to meet Federad Aid, as follows: Roads _ $3,093,262.00 Vocational Education 100,000.00 Bovine Tuberculosis 75,000.00 Hog Cholera 15,000.00 Social Hygiene 25,925.00 This means that the federal government will turn over to the State for these funds approximately $3,309,187.00. The further increased appropriations are practically all for education, maintenance of slate institutions and for the new Capitol. A 4.S0 mill levy will raise approximately $2,735,600.00, which I deem rcient to meet the demand of the General Fund of 1919. The following table will show the amounts that will be derived from the special levies made by the Legislature, and over which the State Board has no control, together with the amount that will be raised for the General Fund: General Fund 4.80 mills $2,735,600.00 Capitol Building Fund 1.50 858,000.00 University Fund 1.00 572 000 03 University Activity Fund _. 0.75 429,000.00 Special University Fund 0.75 429,000.00 Normal School Fund 1.00 572,000." 0 State Aid Road Fund 3.00 1,716,000.00 State Aid Bridge Fund _ ." 0.20 114,400.00 Total $7,426,000.00 Respectfully submitted, GEO. W. MARSH, State Auditor. It was moved by Cropsey and seconded by Marsh, that the Levy for the General Fund be fixed at 8.80 mills in addition to the Special Levies made by the Legislature making a total of 13.00 mills and the Secretary was instructed to certify the Levy to the County Clerks as adopted. All voting yes. Motion made to adjourn, carried.
